content.description: Climb the leftmost feature on the 45 wall. Start low. Top out.
Start on the jug ledge. Make long move with right hand to an oval shaped slopercrimp. Grab a small incut crimp. Keep crimping. Top out.
A bit more difficult and tenuous than the Cobra. The Mongoose eats the Cobra. Great line, even if the Cobra is still cooler.
content.location: It's two lines to the right of the Cobra. The line in between them climbs through a crack but then hits some rotten rock. That one may not have been topped out.

content.description: Very unique problem for SWPA. Super steep, very long tosses between jugs, then a technical and spicy topout. It's probably V6 whether you top it out or drop at the jug at the lip. It's not a bad idea to work the topout on a rope first, since the ground drops away a bit and it gets quite high. The picture is of the first couple holds on the route.Â
content.protection: Lots of pads. Consider TRing the topout first.
content.location: Obvious line of jugs that bust out the middle of the cave.

content.description: This is the impressive bouldering cave located at the far right end of the cliffband. Very unique feature in SWPA. Definitely makes this spot destination-worthy, and it's a fine choice on a rainy day. The two plum lines are The Cobra (v6) (climber is grabbing holds) and the Mongoose (V8) (which is two lines to the right, climbing on the rightmost edge of the cave) which are highballs if done all the way to the top, but dropping off at the lip of the cave is also possible. There are also some good moderate lines that traverse or don't top out.
